description: First attested in the 1610s. Probably from Middle English *titeren, *titren (attested in Middle English titering (“hesitation, vacillation”)), probably a frequentative of Middle English titten (“to waver”), related to  Old Norse titra (“to shake, shiver, quiver”), dialectal Swedish tittra (“to snicker”).

entries.meaning: A nervous or somewhat repressed giggle.
examples: There was a titter of  […]  delight on his countenance.

verbs.description: titter (third-person singular simple present titters, present participle tittering, simple past and past participle tittered)

entries.meaning: To laugh or giggle in a somewhat subdued or restrained way, as from nervousness or poorly-suppressed amusement.
examples: A group of tittering pages ran before.

entries.meaning: (slang, vulgar, chiefly in the plural) A woman's breast.
